title-group.article-title: Preface to the Special Section on Methods for the Analysis of Communication

author-notes.corresp: Nancy J. Cooke, PhD, Cognitive Science and Engineering, Arizona State University, 7271 E. Sonoran Arroyo Mall, Mesa, AZ 85212; e-mail: ncooke@asu.edu.

article-meta.issue-title: Special Section: Methods for the Analysis of Communication

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright © 2012, Human Factors and Ergonomics Society

sec.title: Why Analyze Communication?
sec.p: Communication is a ubiquitous behavior of dyads, groups, teams, and organizations. It is one of the primary vehicles for group interaction, and thus, communication data provide a rich record of interaction processes. When the group or team is engaged in a cognitive task (versus a physical one), its communication reveals cognitive processing at the group or team level (Cooke, Gorman, & Rowe, 2009; Cooke, Gorman, & Winner, 2007). In fact, communication can be likened to a group-level think-aloud. However, in this case, the verbal protocol does not have to be elicited; it occurs naturally, “in the wild.”

In this special section of Human Factors, the term communication analysis is used broadly to include a number of specific types of analyses that are based on different characteristics of communication (e.g., some are analyses of words; some of voice; and some are analyses of interactions among people). Broadly defined, communication analysis enables us to study cognitive processes that operate at the system level, including sociotechnical systems (e.g., Cooke, Gorman, & Kiekel, 2008). Whereas discrete laboratory trials (e.g., stimulus-process-response methods) may be appropriate for understanding isolated cognitive phenomena, cognitive processes that depend on more complex and distributed human–human, human–machine, and temporal relations (e.g., teams and other divided labor systems) are not directly observable with traditional laboratory measures, such as error rate and response time. Communication analysis fills this gap by allowing us to directly observe cognition as the human–human and human–machine interactions unfold temporally.

Data derived from communication studies provide an excellent resource for understanding the propagation of peoples’ reasoning and decision making in complex task environments. Communication analysis, for example, can help uncover “resident pathogens” (Reason, 1990) that may lead to human error in complex environments. Accordingly, communication analysis can produce results that have implications for assessment, training, and the design of complex sociotechnical systems. Although there are social and ethical concerns that need to be addressed in using such analyses in the workplace (McCormack, Duchon, Geyer, & Orvis, 2009), the potential to improve team and organizational performance through the use of such analyses is great. However, to understand how to improve performance, we must first understand what aspects of performance are captured by communication data.

sec.title: Significant Advances in State of the Art
sec.p: Technology developed in the past two decades has made advances in communication analysis possible, and today, the modern workplace provides a wide range of digital communications channels, such as e-mail, chat, instant messaging, voice-over-IP (VoIP) phones, and teleconferencing. Recent technology is making face-to-face interactions easily recordable as well (Olguín et al., 2009). Without these technologies, manual transcription and hand coding of transcripts would be quite laborious.

Today, digitized data-capture techniques continue to expand and improve the efficiency of the transcription process. However, communication-capturing technology often does not automatically transcribe it. Although speech-to-text software ably captures one person’s talk, effectively capturing and transcribing conversations of two or more people is much more difficult, although progress is being made (Hain et al., 2010). After the content is obtained, either automatically or through manual transcription, evidence suggests that it can be used to assess performance. For example, teams can be classified as novice or expert in terms of the words they use (e.g., Foltz, Bolstad, Cuevas, Franzke, & Costello, 2008; Lakkaraju, Stevens-Adams, Abbott, & Forsythe, 2011). The content can also be examined for specific indicators or dialogue acts (e.g., Duchon & Jackson, 2010; Goodman et al., 2005), which can be a way to capture the self-assessment by the participants themselves.

These types of communication analyses are typical of human factors research, as the focus is often on performance. In other disciplines, the focus of communication analyses is often on messages and the meanings messages create. For example, in psychology, Tschan, Gautschi, Hunziker, Spychiger, and Marsch (2006) explore how group coordination is manifested in the conversations of members of emergency medical teams. Communication scholars Keyton and Beck (2009) explore the intersection of task and relational messages in meeting the relational needs of members of a breast cancer support group.

Communication in naturalistic settings, laboratory environments, and focused studies (e.g., think-alouds, case studies, focus groups, mock juries) can generate massive amounts of data beyond just the words spoken. The different aspects of speech (e.g., physical features, such as intonation, pitch, and volume; temporal features, such as timing or tempo; sequencing; etc.) as well as nonverbal information, such as posture, gaze, and gesture, engender additional complexity. Automated routines to collate, categorize, and quantitatively describe these aspects of communication are also progressing (Gatica-Perez, 2009). This type of information can also provide indications of team performance. For example, patterns of communication flow (devoid of content) have been found to be indicative of team performance and workload (Cooke, Gorman, Kiekel, Foltz, & Martin, 2005).

The strengths, limitations, and preferred applications of these new methods are not clear. One approach to this problem is to compare and contrast methods with the use of a common data set. Various corpora have been made available for the purposes of machine learning, for example, regarding meetings (International Computer Science Institute corpus; Janin et al., 2003; the Augmented Multi-party Interaction corpus; McCowan et al., 2005), e-mails (the British Columbia Conversation corpus; Ulrich, Murray, & Carenini, 2008), and virtual math tutors (Stahl, 2009). However, corpora having group interaction data on tasks and task performance data are not generally available. Moving toward this goal, a number of the authors in this special issue used a data set released to participants in an Office of Naval Research (ONR) workshop (described next). Recently, a new effort, also being sponsored by ONR, has begun to create a canonical corpus of experimental data containing both communication and team performance measures.

sec.title: Communication Analysis Workshop
sec.p: A workshop held in February 2010 brought together a number of researchers who applied communication analysis methods in their work. The group was eclectic and represented disciplines of engineering, business, psychology, human factors, communication, and education. Participants had engaged in the analysis of communication for a variety of purposes, including theory development and applications for problems in education, the military, and health care.

Prior to the workshop, we e-mailed participants two communication data sets (one from a health care domain and the other from a military domain), and they were asked to address the analysis of these data using their preferred methods. Most participants addressed the application of their techniques to these types of data sets, and many actually analyzed the data using their methods. Interestingly, despite the wide array of methods, there was remarkable consistency in the interpretation of the analyzed data. In addition, this exercise provided participants deeper insight into each other’s approaches.

Methods were presented at the workshop, and areas of significant progress and gaps were identified. The discussion of those gaps highlighted the need for a compendium of methods as well as the use of a common data set for illustrating and comparing various methods. In addition, there were requests from the human factors community to provide instructional material on communication analysis methods. This request led to two Human Factors and Ergonomics Society workshops on communication analyses that were well attended. This special section is the first step toward a compendium of methods. We hope that these interesting examples of communication analysis methods and their applications will lead to additional work in this area that will form the basis for a compendium of methods.

sec.title: This Special Section
sec.p: The six articles published in this special section highlight a number of methods and applications. The articles by Stevens, Galloway, Wang, and Berka and Gorman, Cooke, Amazeen, and Fouse present methods that can tie very basic communication information to changes in team state. In addition, Stevens et al. show how data from electroencephalogram recordings can complement the communication data to assess team cognition. Khawala, Chen, and Marcus are able to identify aspects of communication data that map to cognitive load; and Calix, Javadpour, and Knapp do the same for affective state. Cavicchio and Poesio examine heart rate and facial expressions to assess cooperation. Similarly, Pfaff shows how communication can itself be affected by affect. We complete this special section with a commentary by Joann Keyton with a number of good recommendations for moving forward in this area.

ack.p: The coeditors of this special section would like to thank the participants of the Communication Analysis Workshop and the Office of Naval Research, which sponsored the workshop through the “Cognition and Collaboration in Network Centric Operations: Understanding and Measuring Macrocognition in Teams” Multidisciplinary University Initiative (ONR No. N00014-06-1-0446).
